unnormalised: We have direct taxes, like income tax (IT), where you pay based on how much you earn. This one's the real crowd-pleaser, because who loves paying taxes? Then there's indirect taxes, like GST, which is levied on goods and services. So, every time you buy that samosa or that new smartphone, you're chipping in a little bit. Don't forget about TDS! Tax Deducted at Source. Basically, if someone pays you a certain amount (say, Rs. 30,000 for some freelance work), they are obligated to deduct a certain percentage as tax and deposit it with the government on your behalf. Think of it as a forced savings scheme, but for the government!

Then there's indirect taxes, like G-S-T, which is levied on goods and services. So, every time you buy that samosa or that new smartphone, you're chipping in a little bit. Don't forget about T-D-S! Tax Deducted at Source. Basically, if someone pays you a certain amount (say, rupee thirty thousand for some freelance work), they are obligated to deduct a certain percentage as tax and deposit it with the government on your behalf. Think of it as a forced savings scheme, but for the government!

unnormalised: Now, the real fun begins with exemptions and deductions. It's like a treasure hunt in the tax code! You can claim deductions for things like investments in PPF, insurance premiums, and even your kids' tuition fees (if you have any). Basically, the government's saying, "Okay, we'll take some of your money, but here are some ways to reduce how much we take, provided you invest it in government-approved things like ELSS mutual funds or contribute to the PM CARES fund, receipt no. 1234567890/2020."

unnormalised: And yes, the Income Tax Department is everywhere. They're like the friendly neighbourhood Spiderman, but instead of saving you from criminals, they’re checking if you've declared all your income and filed your ITR (Income Tax Return) by the due date, usually July 31st. Remember to file on time; otherwise, you might get a notice, and that's never a fun letter to receive.
